AII IT Playbook v1.0

Cloud & FinOpsTerraform IaC

Terraform IaC Guideline

40 min read

Infrastructure as Code best practices for managing AWS resources with Terraform.

Chapter 1

Introduction to Infrastructure as Code

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is the practice of managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable configuration files rather than manual processes.

Version ControlledTrack all infrastructure changes in Git
ReproducibleDeploy identical environments consistently
AutomatedEliminate manual configuration errors
DocumentedCode IS the documentation
AuditableReview changes before applying
ReusableShare modules across teams

Why Terraform?

Multi-Cloud Support

Single tool for AWS, Azure, GCP, and 3000+ providers

Declarative Syntax

Describe desired state, Terraform figures out how

State Management

Tracks real-world resources and their relationships

Execution Plans

Preview changes before applying them

Terraform Core Workflow

terraform init

Initialize backend & providers

terraform plan

Preview changes

terraform apply

Apply changes

terraform destroy

Tear down

Chapter 2

Project Structure

A well-organized Terraform project enables maintainability and team collaboration.

Recommended Project Layout

terraform-project/
environments/
dev/
main.tf
# Dev environment config
variables.tf
terraform.tfvars
prod/
main.tf
# Production config
variables.tf
terraform.tfvars
modules/
vpc/
main.tf
variables.tf
outputs.tf
README.md
ec2/
main.tf
variables.tf
outputs.tf
rds/
main.tf
variables.tf
outputs.tf
backend.tf
# Remote state config
providers.tf
# Provider versions
versions.tf
# Terraform version
.gitignore
README.md

Standard Module Files

main.tfPrimary resource definitions
variables.tfInput variable declarations
outputs.tfOutput value declarations
providers.tfProvider configuration
versions.tfTerraform & provider version constraints
backend.tfRemote state backend configuration
terraform.tfvarsVariable values (environment-specific)
hclversions.tf
terraform {
  required_version = ">= 1.5.0"

  required_providers {
    aws = {
      source  = "hashicorp/aws"
      version = "~> 5.0"
    }
  }
}
Chapter 3

State Management

Terraform state is your source of truth. Manage it carefully.

Critical: Never Commit State Files

State files contain sensitive data (passwords, keys). Always use remote backends and add *.tfstate to .gitignore.

hclbackend.tf - S3 Remote Backend with DynamoDB Locking
terraform {
  backend "s3" {
    bucket         = "axa-terraform-state"
    key            = "prod/infrastructure.tfstate"
    region         = "ap-southeast-1"
    encrypt        = true
    dynamodb_table = "terraform-locks"
    
    # Optional: Use IAM role for cross-account access
    # role_arn     = "arn:aws:iam::123456789012:role/TerraformRole"
  }
}
State Best Practices
  • â€¢ Use remote backends (S3, Azure Blob, GCS)
  • â€¢ Enable state locking (DynamoDB for AWS)
  • â€¢ Enable encryption at rest
  • â€¢ Enable versioning for rollback
  • â€¢ Separate state per environment
    • Avoid These Mistakes
  • â€¢ Never edit state files manually
  • â€¢ Don't commit .tfstate to Git
  • â€¢ Don't share state across unrelated projects
  • â€¢ Don't skip state locking
  • â€¢ Don't ignore state drift warnings
    • hclCreating S3 Backend Infrastructure
    # Run this first (with local state), then migrate
resource "aws_s3_bucket" "terraform_state" {
  bucket = "axa-terraform-state"

  lifecycle {
    prevent_destroy = true
  }
}

resource "aws_s3_bucket_versioning" "terraform_state" {
  bucket = aws_s3_bucket.terraform_state.id
  versioning_configuration {
    status = "Enabled"
  }
}

resource "aws_s3_bucket_server_side_encryption_configuration" "terraform_state" {
  bucket = aws_s3_bucket.terraform_state.id
  rule {
    apply_server_side_encryption_by_default {
      sse_algorithm = "AES256"
    }
  }
}

resource "aws_dynamodb_table" "terraform_locks" {
  name         = "terraform-locks"
  billing_mode = "PAY_PER_REQUEST"
  hash_key     = "LockID"

  attribute {
    name = "LockID"
    type = "S"
  }
}
    Chapter 4

    Modules & Reusability

    Create reusable, composable infrastructure components.

    Single Responsibility

    One module = one logical resource group

    Semantic Versioning

    Version modules for safe upgrades

    Clear Interfaces

    Well-defined inputs and outputs

    hclmodules/vpc/main.tf - Reusable VPC Module
    resource "aws_vpc" "main" {
  cidr_block           = var.cidr_block
  enable_dns_hostnames = true
  enable_dns_support   = true

  tags = merge(var.tags, {
    Name = "${var.environment}-vpc"
  })
}

resource "aws_subnet" "private" {
  count             = length(var.availability_zones)
  vpc_id            = aws_vpc.main.id
  cidr_block        = cidrsubnet(var.cidr_block, 4, count.index)
  availability_zone = var.availability_zones[count.index]

  tags = merge(var.tags, {
    Name = "${var.environment}-private-${count.index + 1}"
    Tier = "private"
  })
}

resource "aws_subnet" "public" {
  count                   = length(var.availability_zones)
  vpc_id                  = aws_vpc.main.id
  cidr_block              = cidrsubnet(var.cidr_block, 4, count.index + length(var.availability_zones))
  availability_zone       = var.availability_zones[count.index]
  map_public_ip_on_launch = true

  tags = merge(var.tags, {
    Name = "${var.environment}-public-${count.index + 1}"
    Tier = "public"
  })
}
    hclUsing the VPC Module
    module "vpc" {
  source = "./modules/vpc"

  cidr_block         = "10.0.0.0/16"
  environment        = "production"
  availability_zones = ["ap-southeast-1a", "ap-southeast-1b"]

  tags = {
    Project     = "MyApp"
    CostCenter  = "IT-Platform"
    ManagedBy   = "Terraform"
  }
}

# Reference outputs from the module
output "vpc_id" {
  value = module.vpc.vpc_id
}

output "private_subnet_ids" {
  value = module.vpc.private_subnet_ids
}
    Chapter 5

    Security Best Practices

    Secure your Terraform workflows and infrastructure code.

    Secrets Management
    Use AWS Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store
    Mark sensitive variables with sensitive = true
    Never hardcode credentials in .tf files
    Use IAM roles instead of access keys
    IAM Least Privilege
    Grant minimum permissions for Terraform execution
    Use separate roles for plan vs apply
    Enable MFA for production changes
    Audit IAM policies regularly
    hclSensitive Variables
    variable "database_password" {
  description = "RDS master password"
  type        = string
  sensitive   = true  # Prevents value from showing in logs
}

# Fetch secret from AWS Secrets Manager
data "aws_secretsmanager_secret_version" "db_password" {
  secret_id = "prod/myapp/db-password"
}

resource "aws_db_instance" "main" {
  # ...
  password = data.aws_secretsmanager_secret_version.db_password.secret_string
}

    Security Scanning Tools

    tflint

    Linter for Terraform code

    tfsec

    Static security analysis

    checkov

    Policy-as-code scanning

    Chapter 6

    CI/CD Integration

    Automate Terraform workflows with Jenkins pipelines.

    GitOps Workflow

    Git as the single source of truth for infrastructure

    Step 1
    Create Branch
    Step 2
    Make Changes
    Step 3
    PR + Plan
    Step 4
    Review + Approve
    Step 5
    Merge + Apply
    groovyJenkinsfile - Terraform Pipeline
    pipeline {
    agent any
    
    environment {
        AWS_DEFAULT_REGION = 'ap-southeast-1'
        TF_IN_AUTOMATION   = 'true'
    }
    
    stages {
        stage('Checkout') {
            steps {
                checkout scm
            }
        }
        
        stage('Terraform Init') {
            steps {
                dir('environments/prod') {
                    sh 'terraform init -input=false'
                }
            }
        }
        
        stage('Terraform Validate') {
            steps {
                dir('environments/prod') {
                    sh 'terraform validate'
                    sh 'tflint --init && tflint'
                    sh 'tfsec .'
                }
            }
        }
        
        stage('Terraform Plan') {
            steps {
                dir('environments/prod') {
                    sh 'terraform plan -out=tfplan -input=false'
                }
            }
        }
        
        stage('Approval') {
            when {
                branch 'main'
            }
            steps {
                input message: 'Review the plan and approve to apply'
            }
        }
        
        stage('Terraform Apply') {
            when {
                branch 'main'
            }
            steps {
                dir('environments/prod') {
                    sh 'terraform apply -auto-approve tfplan'
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    post {
        always {
            cleanWs()
        }
    }
}
    Chapter 7

    AWS Provider Patterns

    Common infrastructure patterns for AWS resources.

    VPC with Public/Private Subnets

    VPC, Subnets, NAT Gateway, IGW

    EC2 with Auto Scaling

    Launch Template, ASG, Target Group

    RDS Multi-AZ

    DB Instance, Subnet Group, Security Group

    S3 with CloudFront

    Bucket, OAI, Distribution, ACM Cert

    hclEC2 Instance with Security Group
    resource "aws_security_group" "web" {
  name        = "${var.environment}-web-sg"
  description = "Security group for web servers"
  vpc_id      = module.vpc.vpc_id

  ingress {
    from_port   = 443
    to_port     = 443
    protocol    = "tcp"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  egress {
    from_port   = 0
    to_port     = 0
    protocol    = "-1"
    cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"]
  }

  tags = var.tags
}

resource "aws_instance" "web" {
  ami                    = data.aws_ami.amazon_linux_2.id
  instance_type          = var.instance_type
  subnet_id              = module.vpc.private_subnet_ids[0]
  vpc_security_group_ids = [aws_security_group.web.id]
  iam_instance_profile   = aws_iam_instance_profile.web.name

  root_block_device {
    volume_type = "gp3"
    volume_size = 20
    encrypted   = true
  }

  tags = merge(var.tags, {
    Name = "${var.environment}-web-server"
  })
}
    Chapter 8

    Tagging & FinOps

    Consistent tagging enables cost allocation and governance.

    hclCommon Tags Variable
    locals {
  common_tags = {
    Environment  = var.environment
    Project      = var.project_name
    CostCenter   = var.cost_center
    Owner        = var.owner_email
    ManagedBy    = "Terraform"
    Repository   = "github.com/axa/infrastructure"
  }
}

# Apply to all resources
resource "aws_instance" "example" {
  # ...
  tags = merge(local.common_tags, {
    Name = "${var.environment}-${var.project_name}-instance"
  })
}
    Tag KeyPurposeExample
    EnvironmentIdentify deployment stage
    production
    ProjectApplication or project name
    claims-api
    CostCenterCost allocation
    IT-Platform
    OwnerTeam or person responsible
    platform-team
    ManagedByHow resource is managed
    Terraform
    Chapter 9

    Workspaces

    Manage multiple environments with Terraform workspaces.

    bashUsing Workspaces
    # Create and switch to a workspace
terraform workspace new dev
terraform workspace new staging
terraform workspace new prod

# List workspaces
terraform workspace list

# Switch workspace
terraform workspace select prod

# Use workspace name in configuration
# terraform.workspace returns current workspace name
    hclEnvironment-Specific Configuration
    locals {
  environment = terraform.workspace
  
  instance_types = {
    dev     = "t3.micro"
    staging = "t3.small"
    prod    = "t3.medium"
  }
  
  instance_counts = {
    dev     = 1
    staging = 2
    prod    = 3
  }
}

resource "aws_instance" "app" {
  count         = local.instance_counts[local.environment]
  instance_type = local.instance_types[local.environment]
  
  tags = {
    Environment = local.environment
  }
}
    Chapter 10

    Case Studies

    Real-world Terraform implementations.

    Three-Tier Web Application
    VPC + ALB + EC2 + RDS architecture

    VPC Three-Tier Architecture

    Public Subnets
    ALB
    Internet-facing
    Private Subnets
    EC2 (ASG)
    App Servers
    RDS
    Multi-AZ DB
    All resources inside VPC with proper security groups
    Serverless API
    API Gateway + Lambda + DynamoDB

    Use Terraform to provision serverless resources with proper IAM roles, VPC connectivity for database access, and CloudWatch logging.

    API Gateway
    Lambda
    DynamoDB
    CloudWatch
